info.game_comments: Player introductions are missing from the tape used to archive the game.

(1, 1).clue: His one & only flight in space lasted 4 hours 55 minutes & consisted of 3 orbits

(2, 1).clue: This airline describes itself as "something special in the air"

(3, 1).clue: According to Shakespeare, this queen liked to play billiards with her eunuch

(4, 1).clue: At last count this state had the greatest number of women behind bars

(5, 1).clue: In the duet "Ebony & Ivory", Stevie Wonder was the ebony while he was the ivory

(6, 1).clue: A $16 million F-16 was destroyed when it hit a pair of these animals "hogging" the runway

(2, 2).clue: A flying red horse is a symbol of this oil company

(3, 2).clue: This fun couple lived in a castle in Inverness

(4, 2).clue: Never allowed B-4, this game is still banned in Abu Dhabi as contrary to Islamic teaching

(5, 2).clue: This singer's only No. 1 hit "American Pie", was so long it had to be divided in half to fit on a 45

(6, 2).clue: The 1st day these were put on Amtrak's Calif. trains, riders used them to tell spouses the train broke down

(2, 3).clue: Ads for this German car say it's "engineered like no other car in the world"

(3, 3).clue: In "Romeo & Juliet", it's the occupation of John & Lawrence

(4, 3).clue: Moscow has declared it illegal for gangs to roar through the city at night on these vehicles

(5, 3).clue: This '50s female group was "Sincerely" one of the best

(6, 3).clue: Instead of children's songs, a mislabelled "Lullaby Magic" tape featured this Jerry Garcia group

(1, 4).clue: In names given to the Mercury capsules Friendship 7 &, Faith 7, etc., the "7" meant this

(2, 4).clue: "The most unforgettable women in the world wear" this

(3, 4).clue: It's how Hamlet finds out his father was murdered

(4, 4).clue: Buying stocks using info not available to the public, you could be fined up to $100,000 for doing it

(5, 4).clue: She got "The Wedding Bell Blues" & Billy Davis Jr. married her

(6, 4).clue: Postal officials predicted by 1988 90% of 1st class mailers would be using these, but only 20% now do

(1, 5).clue: Apollo 11 astronaut who tells the history of U.S. manned spaceflight in the 1988 book "Liftoff"

(2, 5).clue: French crystal "at the service of monarchs, luminaries, statesmen & mere perfectionists since 1764"

(3, 5).clue: Characters in this comedy include Shallow, Simple, Slender & Falstaff

(4, 5).clue: In '84 the Supreme Court ruled the practice of "time shifting" with one of these didn't violate copyrights

(5, 5).clue: When Stevie Nicks isn't singing lead for Fleetwood Mac, she usually is

(6, 5).clue: A '88 Cannes Film Festival juror sat with Nastassja Kinski thinking she was this star of "Blue Velvet"

(2, 1).clue: In the line widely attributed to P.T. Barnum, it's how often a sucker is born

(3, 1).clue: As this church celebrated its 1000th anniversary, it was granted new freedom by Gorbachev

(4, 1).clue: The capital of Austria's Tyrol Province in this city in the Inn Valley

(5, 1).clue: Classified 4-F during WWII, this swashbuckling Tasmanian only fought on film

(6, 1).clue: The friends who bought them a house in Bel Air on St. Cloud Dr. changed the address from 666 to 668

(1, 2).clue: The grave of this wild west scout & showman is on top of Lookout Mountain near Golden, Colo.

(2, 2).clue: He called religion "the opium of the people"

(3, 2).clue: Church founded in the 1950s in the U.S. by former sci-fi writer L. Ron Hubbard

(4, 2).clue: World's largest active volcano, its name is Hawaiian for "mountain long"

(5, 2).clue: This actor married 3 actresses: Jill Esmond,Vivien Leigh &Joan Plowright

(6, 2).clue: A number of states are blaming 1988 budget gaps on changes in this in 1987

(1, 3).clue: To cowboys, "hair pants" were this accessory with the hair left on the hide

(2, 3).clue: He coined the phrase "Here's a pretty kettle of fish" in the operetta "Iolanthe"

(3, 3).clue: Originally built to house the ashes of Buddha, stupas evolved into these in S.E. Asia

(4, 3).clue: World's largest producer of cloves & vanilla is this large island, southeast of Zanzibar

(5, 3).clue: Morgan Fairchild was Faye Dunaway's stand-in for this film & even dated Warren Beatty

(6, 3).clue: A new statue in the Paris Tuileries is of this Jewish soldier tried for treason & later exonerated

(1, 4).clue: As a result of the Gunfight at the O.K. Corral, Virgil Earp lost his job as marshal of this city

(2, 4).clue: Part of the inscription on the Statue of Liberty reads, "I lift my lamp beside" this

(4, 4).clue: The Caspian Sea, largest lake in the world is bounded by the USSR & this country

(5, 4).clue: Born Alec de Cuffe, he was illegitimate & has never learned his father's identity

(6, 4).clue: 1st diamond of this color to be put on permanent display was unveiled by the Smithsonian in 1988

(1, 5).clue: Imprisoned in 1881, Billy the Kid appealed to this governor who was too busy promoting his novel to help

(2, 5).clue: After his 1817 surrender, this Indian chief said, "I will fight no more forever"

(4, 5).clue: The widest part of South America is 3,200 miles across & extends from Brazil to the coast of this country

(5, 5).clue: Frank Capra said this co-star of "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town" is his favorite actress

(0, 0).clue: This California teenager was the 1st American to win a regular gold medal at the 1988 Summer Olympics
